issue.title: `tests bench` script should fail if binaries fail
issue.body:
**Issue:** `scripts/tests/bench` does not fail if the benchmarking binaries fail.

Example output:
```
~/repos/mlkem-c-aarch64$ ./scripts/tests bench --cycles PERF
INFO  > benchmark
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber512
INFO  > MLKEM512 passed
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber768
INFO  > MLKEM768 passed
INFO  > make CYCLES=PERF test/bin/bench_kyber1024
INFO  > MLKEM1024 passed
MLKEM512

MLKEM768

MLKEM1024
```

Here, the issue was that access to `perf` was missing, as witnessed when running the binaries separately:
```
~/repos/mlkem-c-aarch64$ ./test/bin/bench_kyber1024
read: Bad file descriptor
```

Another issue is that switching between `CYCLES=NO/PMU/PERF` requires `make clean` and rebuild, which is not yet documented.

**Task:**
- [ ]  Fix `tests` so that it fails if the test/bench binaries fail. Ideally, don't mask `stderr`.
- [ ] Document that `make clean` is needed when switching between `NO/PERF/PMU`, or -- even better -- detect the switch and rebuild automatically.

comment.body:
Thanks. @potsrevennil and I will have a look at this next week. 

The catching of failures is not limited to benchmarks I believe. The rc should also be checked for the other tests, but I guess those have never failed so far.

Unfortunately, I can't make it today due to a conflicting metting. Apologies. 
@hanno-becker can give an update on the work we have been doing on mlkem-c-aarch64 in the past two weeks. We've merged quite a few pull requests.

issue.title: Add benchmark workflow (RPi4 / Arm Cortex-A72)

labels.name: benchmark
labels.description: this PR should be benchmarked in CI

issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR depends on #68

I Added a benchmark workflow. Note that the workflow will only run on `main` branch or PR labeled as `benchmark`. The `tests` script is also refactored a bit in order to show the benchmark summary on GitHub action.

I refactored the `nix` shell specification in order to speed up ci, and also
disabled ci jobs running on self-host runner when pushed to fork repositories by the way.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->

comment.body:
@hanno-becker Yeah, I agree with you that it indeed makes more sense in some cases to separate building and running the binary. There're also cases that we would like to run the binaries in a different machine.

However, I'm thinking this might a bit out of scope for this PR, maybe we could open an issue to address this more, and make it a separate PR. What do you think ?

issue.title: Access to AWS AArch64 runners
issue.body:
Relates to: #55 

AWS Graviton2 and Graviton3 instances are among the current benchmarking targets for MLKEM-C-AArch64 (see [README](https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64) for the others, though note this list may still evolve).

The purpose of this issue is to track if/how we could provide access to AWS Graviton-based runners for MLKEM-C-AArch64 in particular, or the PQCP the general.

comment.body: Tagging @ry who has done some initial investigation here.

issue.title: Introduce common coeff_signed_to_unsigned function in poly.c
issue.body:
This PR introduces a common "coeff_signed_to_unsigned()" function in poly.c, its contracts and verification thereof using CBMC. This function reduces repetition of the same idiom in poly.c and simplifies the calling code in poly_compress() and other functions.

Additionally, this PR adds contract-based proof of scalar_compress_q_16 and scalar_compress_q_32

comment.body: @rod-chapman , can you do the honor, test the "update with rebase" button?

comment.body:
@hanno-becker I have a question maybe not that related to this PR. 

I noticed that in here
https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/blob/95615fc0c742cf4b3ace32e0578d830d9447751a/.github/workflows/ci.yml#L117-L122

Since we are using `bash` with the `-e` flag, seems like if the previous proof failed, the following proof will not be executed, is this as expected ?
